pullRequest.body:
This PR removes the default values for `nsmul` and `zsmul`, forcing the user to populate them manually.
The previous behavior can be obtained by writing `nsmul := nsmulRec` and `zsmul := zsmulRec`, which is now in the docstring for these fields.

The motivation here is to make it more obvious when module diamonds are being introduced, or at least where they might be hiding; you can now simply search for `nsmulRec` in the source code.

Arguably we should do the same thing for `intCast`, `natCast`, `pow`, and `zpow` too, but diamonds are less common in those fields, so I'll leave them to a subsequent PR.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
-->
- [x] depends on: #6265

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

This was particularly bad in light of https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/issues/2387, which encouraged us (in order to avoid a performance issue) to write `{ nsmul := foo.nsmul, toY := foo.toY, z := z }` instead of `{ foo with z := z }`; if `nsmul := ` is forgotten in this case, a new diamond is created.

nodes.body: Could this be related to why Algebra.Category.ModuleCat.Limits compiles more slowly after https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6144 ? Or are your changes colimit-only?

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#6265~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

~~Related and I can't find where this was discussed before: why are [AddCommMonoid.natModule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Basic.html#AddCommMonoid.natModule) and [AddCommGroup.intModule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Basic.html#AddCommGroup.intModule) instances?~~

~~[AddMonoidHom.toRatLinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LinearMap.html#AddMonoidHom.toRatLinearMap) correctly adds the [Module Q _] typeclass assumptions but [AddMonoidHom.toNatLinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LinearMap.html#AddMonoidHom.toNatLinearMap) and [AddMonoidHom.toIntLinearMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LinearMap.html#AddMonoidHom.toIntLinearMap) rely on the two diamond-prone instances above.~~

Oh I see those instances are safe since `AddMonoid` already contains the `nsmul` field. The diamonds [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/d7030312d9695e27ffe77ad72f57783389f2ef51/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/GroupCat/Injective.lean#L63-L66) are due to `nsmul` from a `Module â„¤ M` instance that is independent of the `AddCommGroup M` instance, while on concrete `M` the former should always arise from the latter.
It looks like I missed the discussion about "don't use with". Could you please turn these words in the commit message into a link to an appropriate Zulip thread?
@urkud: updated.

Can you update the PR message to current times? Thanks.

bors delegate+

:v: eric-wieser can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Thanks for solving the conflicts; I assume they'll be a few rounds of build failures next, which I can look at.
`Mathlib` builds and lints ðŸ˜‰
I'm not sure how you came to that conclusion since you committed a merge conflict marker ðŸ™ƒ
Well it does on my machine.
Ah, you were technically correct; the conflict marked was in `Counterexamples`, as was the build failure. Now fixed.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/9b937f50-1070-4d27-b453-09a41e846409) for commit c85d804b5a313b64c0216373e7e999247095ca2c.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/52f45c30-47e9-40b9-bc7a-e559098c2884/to/9b937f50-1070-4d27-b453-09a41e846409) against commit cb921c1cdc041fa66802c02d67784c1addeee945:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                  Metric         Change
  ================================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.Module.PID                                instructions    -5.5%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Preadditive.FunctorCategory        instructions   -47.5%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Sites.Sheaf                        instructions   -22.6%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Action.Limits                instructions   -47.0%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.GroupCohomology.Basic        instructions   -20.5%
+ ~Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.GroupCohomology.Resolution   instructions    -7.2%
```

Well that's a nice bonus

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8213638536/job/22465263172)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8213638536/job/22465263000)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8213638536/job/22465262935)
I didn't compare the profiles before and after but I guess unification is not unfolding `+` now in some checks?
Doesn't this indicate that it would be better to declare the Zero and Add instances separately?
Does it matter if we're using `letI`, because this just inlines everything.
I think my patch behaves exactly the same as what we currently do, though I haven't checked. (Yours generates a smaller term.)
I've pulled this out as requested.
ditto
This is a `def`, so pulling these out is impractical.
ditto
Done
